issue.title: [GraphBolt] upgrade CUDA to 17 and update CI gpu image to torch2.0+cu118
issue.body:
## Description
<!-- Brief description. Refer to the related issues if existed.
It'll be great if relevant reviewers can be assigned as well.-->
CUDA STANDARD from 14 to 17
upgrade cmake from 3.15 to 3.18 in CI docker images.
## Checklist
Please feel free to remove inapplicable items for your PR.
- [ ] The PR title starts with [$CATEGORY] (such as [NN], [Model], [Doc], [Feature]])
- [ ] I've leverage the [tools](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1iHyj7zlmygKSk5gBPsqIqL5ASPzJSPREaNT_QdsiYA4/edit) to beautify the python and c++ code.
- [ ] The PR is complete and small, read the [Google eng practice (CL equals to PR)](https://google.github.io/eng-practices/review/developer/small-cls.html) to understand more about small PR. In DGL, we consider PRs with less than 200 lines of core code change are small (example, test and documentation could be exempted).
- [ ] All changes have test coverage
- [ ] Code is well-documented
- [ ] To the best of my knowledge, examples are either not affected by this change, or have been fixed to be compatible with this change
- [ ] Related issue is referred in this PR
- [ ] If the PR is for a new model/paper, I've updated the example index [here](../examples/README.md).

## Changes
<!-- You could use following template
- [ ] Feature1, tests, (and when applicable, API doc)
- [ ] Feature2, tests, (and when applicable, API doc)
-->

pull_request.title: [GraphBolt] Modify random hetero graph generation in tests.
pull_request.body:

<!-- Brief description. Refer to the related issues if existed.

repo.name: dgl
repo.description: Python package built to ease deep learning on graph, on top of existing DL frameworks.

issue.title: [Example] add ogc method
issue.body:
## Description

 An implementation of OGC method from the paper [From Cluster Assumption to Graph Convolution: Graph-based Semi-Supervised Learning Revisited](https://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13599). 

OGC is a simple but very powerful graph convolution method, with only one trainable layer. Our initial proposal of the model mainly contains two files: utils.py which defines some basic functions, and main.py which shows the training progress.

**Table 1: Node classification accuracy (%).**

|    Acc    | CiteSeer | Cora | PubMed |
| :-------: | :------: | :--: | :----: |
|    GCN (DGL)    |   71.0   | 81.0 |  79.0  |
| GRAND (DGL) | 74.0 | 83.7 | 78.8 |
| GATv2 (DGL)| 70.3 | 81.0 | 77.1 |
| OGC (DGL) |   77.4 | **86.9** |  **83.6**  |
| OGC (Reported) |   **77.5**   | **86.9** |  83.4  |

**Table 2: Running time (s).**

|   Time    | CiteSeer | Cora | PubMed |
| :-------: | :------: | :--: | :----: |
|    GCN (DGL)   |   7.8   | 4.7 |  9.7  |
| GRAND (DGL) | 248.7 | 99.6 | 237.8 |
| GATv2 (DGL) | 17.51 | 11.71 | 44.44|
| OGC (DGL) |   **2.18**   | **0.95** |  **1.87**  |

We use three DGL's built_in datasets (Citeseer, Cora and Pubmed) with their default train/val/test settings. As shown above, OGC has a substantial improvement, with 100-200X high efficiency compared to SOTA deep GNNs.

We are very happy to further improve the code for this great project, and will continue to contribute actively!

Author: [Sinuo Xu](https://github.com/SinuoXu) (undergraduate, @SJTU) advised by [Dr. Zheng Wang@SJTU](https://zhengwang100.github.io/).

## Checklist
Please feel free to remove inapplicable items for your PR.
- [√] The PR title starts with [$CATEGORY] (such as [NN], [Model], [Doc], [Feature]])
- [√] I've leverage the [tools](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1iHyj7zlmygKSk5gBPsqIqL5ASPzJSPREaNT_QdsiYA4/edit) to beautify the python and c++ code.
- [√] The PR is complete and small, read the [Google eng practice (CL equals to PR)](https://google.github.io/eng-practices/review/developer/small-cls.html) to understand more about small PR. In DGL, we consider PRs with less than 200 lines of core code change are small (example, test and documentation could be exempted).
- [√] All changes have test coverage
- [√] Code is well-documented
- [ ] If the PR is for a new model/paper, I've updated the example index [here](../examples/README.md).

labels.name: Work Item
labels.description: Work items tracked in project tracker

issue.body:
## 🔨Work Item

**IMPORTANT:**
* This template is only for dev team to track project progress. For feature request or bug report, please use the corresponding issue templates.
* DO NOT create a new work item if the purpose is to fix an existing issue or feature request. We will directly use the issue in the project tracker.

Project tracker: https://github.com/orgs/dmlc/projects/2

## Description

<!-- short description of the work item -->

## Depending work items or issues

<!-- what must be done before this -->

comment.body: Yes, we are looking into options that can improve on-disk feature index-select. If you have more recommendation in mind, please let us know, we will investigate.

We use three DGL's built_in datasets (Citeseer, Cora and Pubmed) with their default train/val/test settings. As shown above, OGC has a substantial improvement, with 100-200X high efficiency compared to SOTA deep GNNs.

We are very happy to further improve the code for this great project, and will continue to contribute actively!

Author: [Sinuo Xu](https://github.com/SinuoXu) (undergraduate, @SJTU) advised by [Dr. Zheng Wang@SJTU](https://zhengwang100.github.io/).

## Checklist
Please feel free to remove inapplicable items for your PR.
- [√] The PR title starts with [$CATEGORY] (such as [NN], [Model], [Doc], [Feature]])
- [√] I've leverage the [tools](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1iHyj7zlmygKSk5gBPsqIqL5ASPzJSPREaNT_QdsiYA4/edit) to beautify the python and c++ code.
- [√] The PR is complete and small, read the [Google eng practice (CL equals to PR)](https://google.github.io/eng-practices/review/developer/small-cls.html) to understand more about small PR. In DGL, we consider PRs with less than 200 lines of core code change are small (example, test and documentation could be exempted).
- [√] All changes have test coverage
- [√] Code is well-documented
- [ ] If the PR is for a new model/paper, I've updated the example index [here](../examples/README.md).

issue.title: [Example] add ogc method
issue.body:
## Description

 An implementation of OGC method from the paper [From Cluster Assumption to Graph Convolution: Graph-based Semi-Supervised Learning Revisited](https://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13599). 

OGC is a simple but very powerful graph convolution method, with only one trainable layer. Our initial proposal of the model mainly contains two files: utils.py which defines some basic functions, and main.py which shows the training progress.

**Table 1: Node classification accuracy (%).**

|    Acc    | CiteSeer | Cora | PubMed |
| :-------: | :------: | :--: | :----: |
|    GCN (DGL)    |   71.0   | 81.0 |  79.0  |
| GRAND (DGL) | 74.0 | 83.7 | 78.8 |
| GATv2 (DGL)| 70.3 | 81.0 | 77.1 |
| OGC (DGL) |   77.4 | **86.9** |  **83.6**  |
| OGC (Reported) |   **77.5**   | **86.9** |  83.4  |

**Table 2: Running time (s).**

|   Time    | CiteSeer | Cora | PubMed |
| :-------: | :------: | :--: | :----: |
|    GCN (DGL)   |   7.8   | 4.7 |  9.7  |
| GRAND (DGL) | 248.7 | 99.6 | 237.8 |
| GATv2 (DGL) | 17.51 | 11.71 | 44.44|
| OGC (DGL) |   **2.18**   | **0.95** |  **1.87**  |

We use three DGL's built_in datasets (Citeseer, Cora and Pubmed) with their default train/val/test settings. As shown above, OGC has a substantial improvement, with 100-200X high efficiency compared to SOTA deep GNNs.

We are very happy to further improve the code for this great project, and will continue to contribute actively!

Author: [Sinuo Xu](https://github.com/SinuoXu) (undergraduate, @SJTU) advised by [Dr. Zheng Wang@SJTU](https://zhengwang100.github.io/).

## Checklist
Please feel free to remove inapplicable items for your PR.
- [√] The PR title starts with [$CATEGORY] (such as [NN], [Model], [Doc], [Feature]])
- [√] I've leverage the [tools](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1iHyj7zlmygKSk5gBPsqIqL5ASPzJSPREaNT_QdsiYA4/edit) to beautify the python and c++ code.
- [√] The PR is complete and small, read the [Google eng practice (CL equals to PR)](https://google.github.io/eng-practices/review/developer/small-cls.html) to understand more about small PR. In DGL, we consider PRs with less than 200 lines of core code change are small (example, test and documentation could be exempted).
- [√] All changes have test coverage
- [√] Code is well-documented
- [ ] If the PR is for a new model/paper, I've updated the example index [here](../examples/README.md).

issue.title: Installation of the version that includes PGExplainer
issue.body:
## ❓ Questions and Help
Hello,

I want to use the PGExplainer method in the latest version. 
https://docs.dgl.ai/en/latest/generated/dgl.nn.pytorch.explain.PGExplainer.html?highlight=pgexplainer

Since the release of the latest version has not been done yet, I tried to install it by following the steps in the link below.
https://docs.dgl.ai/en/latest/install/index.html

Below is the error I got:
```bash
-- Build files have been written to: /home/kiymet/Documents/pyod-test/dgl/dgl_sparse/build/1.13.0
Scanning dependencies of target dgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0
[  7%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/dgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0.dir/src/cpu/matrix_ops_impl.cc.o
[ 14%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/dgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0.dir/src/elemenwise_op.cc.o
[ 21%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/dgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0.dir/src/matmul.cc.o
[ 28%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/dgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0.dir/src/matrix_ops.cc.o
[ 35%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/dgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0.dir/src/python_binding.cc.o
[ 42%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/dgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0.dir/src/reduction.cc.o
[ 50%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/dgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0.dir/src/sddmm.cc.o
[ 57%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/dgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0.dir/src/softmax.cc.o
[ 64%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/dgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0.dir/src/sparse_format.cc.o
[ 71%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/dgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0.dir/src/sparse_matrix.cc.o
[ 78%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/dgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0.dir/src/sparse_matrix_coalesce.cc.o
[ 85%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/dgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0.dir/src/spmm.cc.o
[ 92%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/dgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0.dir/src/spspmm.cc.o
[100%] Linking CXX executable runUnitTests
[100%] Built target runUnitTests
/home/kiymet/Documents/pyod-test/dgl/dgl_sparse/src/matrix_ops.cc: In function ‘std::tuple<c10::intrusive_ptr<dgl::sparse::SparseMatrix, c10::detail::intrusive_target_default_null_type<dgl::sparse::SparseMatrix> >, at::Tensor> dgl::sparse::Compact(const c10::intrusive_ptr<dgl::sparse::SparseMatrix>&, uint64_t, at::Tensor)’:
/home/kiymet/Documents/pyod-test/dgl/dgl_sparse/src/matrix_ops.cc:67:1: warning: control reaches end of non-void function [-Wreturn-type]
   67 | }
      | ^
[100%] Linking CXX shared library libdgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0.so
[100%] Built target dgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0
'libdgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0.so' -> '/home/kiymet/Documents/pyod-test/dgl/build/dgl_sparse/libdgl_sparse_pytorch_1.13.0.so'
[100%] Built target dgl_sparse
```

I also checked the https://discuss.dgl.ai/ website as suggested, but I could not find an example with a similar problem.

Do you mind sharing the release date of the next version (which includes the PGExplainer)? 
I could install the latest pip version which does not include PGExplainer (1.1.2).
Until then, what steps should I follow to be able to use PGExplainer?
Thanks in advance.

comment.body: Hi @kiymetkaya , I am closing this issue assuming you are happy about our response. Feel free to follow up and reopen the issue if you have more questions with regard to our response.

issue.title: Can't build DGL graphbolt after #6417
issue.body:
## 🐛 Bug

Can't build DGL graphbolt after #6417

This code sets the C++ standard to 14, where pytorch now requires extensions to be built with C++ 17 compilers.

https://github.com/dmlc/dgl/commit/1b5b7de5daef4fbc93934e525ab3c0e8c7d029d1#diff-b34a77a2d1f5909475ff6bf53a5d34477c1a5a765e2d43bc04b68596ec3b4526R60-R64

https://github.com/dmlc/dgl/blob/1b5b7de5daef4fbc93934e525ab3c0e8c7d029d1/graphbolt/CMakeLists.txt#L60-L63

Not sure why it's set to 14, but I'm able to build the project simply changing that to 17.

comment.body: Yes, let's change it to 17. @Rhett-Ying to take care just in case there are any unexpected issue.

issue.title: NameError: name '_CAPI_DGLRPCReset' is not defined when calling `dgl.distributed.initialize()`
issue.body:
## 🐛 Bug

<!-- A clear and concise description of what the bug is. -->

## To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Install DGL CPU version on an M1 Macbook
2. Run `import dgl; dgl.distributed.initialize()` in a Python REPL


Stacktrace:

```
dgl.distributed.initialize(ip_config=None)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/thvasilo/.pyenv/versions/jupyter-env/lib/python3.9/site-packages/dgl/distributed/dist_context.py", line 284, in initialize
    rpc.reset()
  File "/Users/thvasilo/.pyenv/versions/jupyter-env/lib/python3.9/site-packages/dgl/distributed/rpc.py", line 138, in reset
    _CAPI_DGLRPCReset()
NameError: name '_CAPI_DGLRPCReset' is not defined
```


## Expected behavior

Trying the same on my Linux instance seems to work fine, not sure if MacOS is the issue here.

## Environment

 - DGL Version (e.g., 1.0): 1.1.2post1
 - Backend Library & Version (e.g., PyTorch 0.4.1, MXNet/Gluon 1.3): CPU
 - OS (e.g., Linux): MacOS
 - How you installed DGL (`conda`, `pip`, source): pip
 - Build command you used (if compiling from source):
 - Python version: 3.9
 - CUDA/cuDNN version (if applicable):
 - GPU models and configuration (e.g. V100):
 - Any other relevant information: M1 Mac (aarch64)

## Additional context
